entry.title: Re: Forecasting in Intercompany Stock Transfer Scenario
entry.content:
Please understand the disconnect in your process

  • Sales demand originates at Plant B, which is responsible for customer-facing activities and should drive the forecast.
  • Consumption postings (e.g., movement types 687, 601) are recorded at Plant A, the supplying plant, due to the nature of intercompany stock transfers.
  • This leads to forecasting inaccuracies, as standard consumption-based forecasting tools in SAP S/4HANA Cloud rely on historical consumption data—available only at Plant A.

So the recommended forecasting strategy would be to consider Plant B as the Forecasting Anchor. Forecasts should be generated based on sales orders and historical demand at Plant B, not consumption at Plant A. This aligns with the business reality that Plant B drives customer demand.

Leverage Advanced Intercompany Stock Transfer (Scope Item 5HP). SAP’s advanced intercompany process includes document flow tracking and valuation in transit, which can help reconcile demand and consumption across plants2. Use the Monitor Value Chains app to trace the flow from sales order at Plant B to goods issue at Plant A.

Use forecasting tools like Predictive Material and Resource Planning (pMRP) or Demand-Driven Replenishment (DDR) with input from Plant B’s sales history. These tools allow manual overrides or external forecast inputs, which can be derived from your custom logic.

There is no standard SAP automation that links consumption at Plant A directly to demand at Plant B for forecasting. Therefore custom logic is essential to bridge this gap. Consider creating a forecast consumption proxy at Plant B using Historical intercompany STOs, Sales order quantities and Delivery schedules.

entry.title: Alternative GR/IR account for procurement
entry.content:
We have a requirement to have an alternative GR/IR account for certain types of consumption/service procurement postings. For this we assigned a valuation class to a material group in the SSCUI 'Entry Aids for Items Without a Material Master' (101602), created a G/L account and configured this in the SSCUI 'Automatic account determination'. But the system is not picking our alternative GL account for the GR/IR posting key in the goods receipt, instead it is posting to the delivered GR/IR Account.

 

 

 


--- Steps to Reproduce ---

Log in into the dev system, and check the configuration. Create the PO for procurment of material group DIGITS and the account detrmination is not rflecting as expected, the one configured. Instead it is taking the standard G/L.



*Note To SAP:
I give approval for SAP Support to use these Steps to Reproduce, while connected to my impacted non-production environments, even if the steps result in a change being made and my approval remains valid until the issue is resolved, unless I inform SAP Support otherwise.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Alternative GR/IR account for procurement
entry.content:
Refer to the SAP KBA 2828996 - How to determine GL account using Material Group

The assignment of a valuation class to a material group is made in the configuration node 'Entry Aids for Items Without a Material Master' (SSCUI: 101602)
Please note that, using this valuation class, the G/L account is determined in the purchase order if no material master record exists.
The determination of the GR/IR clearing account always takes place with an initial valuation class.

entry.title: Setup communication of SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition for e-submission
entry.content:
In this blog post, I would like to provide a step-by-step guide to help you configure and integrate SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition or SAP S/4HANA Private Edition, specifically for electronic submission of statutory reports.

The communication and integration of SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition is available for a number of supported compliance reports per country / region (in both S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition or On-Premise). Through the list(s) above, all already delivered supported compliance tasks which relates to Submitting Statutory Reports Using SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, Cloud Edition as supported submission types are relevant for communication setup and application configuration. 

This blog post will provide you with a walkthrough to help you navigate through the different configuration aspects within the SAP Help portal.  With simple setup steps and the configuration of your environment you will achieve proper communication of your business system with SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition and authentication to the tax authorities. 

The value of the integration between SAP S/4HANA business systems and SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition lies in the fact the setup of the various steps shown below need to be done only once for communication purpose – once done the main communication is then available for all reports.

Then, once you have completed specific application configuration for your reporting entity and communication settings specific for your report, a single click submits the report from your business system (through the application Run Statutory Reporting) and triggers the entire flow to electronic submit to the tax authority.

The configuration/set up required for each compliance report is depicted below:

Configuration on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition business system:

  • Scope Item Activation (78L): Before starting, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition must have the communication scenario SAP_COM_0854 available for configuration of the communication in your business system.  If your report is listed on the S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition supported compliance tasks with supported submission type as  Submitting Statutory Reports Using SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, Cloud Edition, please request activation of the scope item 78L (more information in the SAP Note 3387894).
  • Onboarding to the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition: If you have entitlement through your license then the next step is the Initial Setup of SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition.
  • Connecting the Cloud Edition and the Business System: After onboarding, you must setup the Integration of SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition with your S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition business system.
    • Communication Setup details, with all the information required, are available at:
      • setup instruction of the scope item 78L or 
      • Integrating All Other Processes and Countries/Regions with SAP S/4HANA Cloud 
  • Reporting Configuration in the Business System and Cloud Edition: The final step is the specific configuration for your report.  Here you need to complete the following two main configurations: 
    • Configure your process-specific setting and authentication method for your reports per country/region in the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition (SAP BTP). Please verify it per your specific report at Process-Specific Setting.
    • Configure each statutory report by following the steps in the individual configuration documentation. This can be found by navigating to the links in the Reports column in the Reports Enabled for Electronic Submission..

Configuration on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition business systems:

  • Implementing Required SAP Notes: Before starting, the SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition or On-Premise must contain the required implementation objects.  Each report includes these note details in the Supported Compliance Tasks by Country/Region table. To find this information, search by Country/Region and Task and the specific Submission Implementation Overview SAP Note. For example, if you search for United Kingdom and the task VAT Return, the Submission Implementation Overview SAP Note 3386362 appears in the Technical Information column.
  • Onboarding to the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition: If you have entitlement through your license then the next step is the Initial Setup of SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition.
  • Connecting the Cloud Edition and the Business System: After onboarding, you must setup the Integration of SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition with your S/4HANA business system.
    • Communication Setup details, with all the information required for the backend setup, are available at: Integrating All Other Processes and Countries/Regions with SAP S/4HANA 
  • Reporting Configuration in the Business System and Cloud Edition: The final step is the specific configuration for your report.  Here you need to complete the following two main configurations: 
    • Configure your process-specific setting and authentication method for your reports per country/region in the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition (SAP BTP). Please verify it per your specific report at Process-Specific Setting.
    • Configure each statutory report by following the steps in the individual configuration documentation. You can find the configuration documentation in SAP S/4HANA by navigating to the links in the Reports column in the Reports Enabled for Electronic Submission.

I hope this guide can provide a comprehensive understanding of the configuration steps and where to find all relevant information for the configuration of the communication setup in SAP S/4HANA Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition and SAP S/4HANA Cloud business systems.

Thank you and see you next time.

entry.title: Provisioning SAP Business Data Cloud Connect and Enrolling with Existing Databricks
entry.content:
Hi, community!

Trust me when I say I know how difficult it may be to follow SAP Help Portal instructions, especially when you have to move from different platforms, let alone having to wait for a button to become visible!

Recently, I worked on some documentation for provisioning SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) Connect and enrolling it with an existing Databricks setup. Since it may seem tricky to perform this task at first, I decided to make a short video to guide you through the process.

Setting up SAP BDC Connect with an existing Databricks environment gives you a dedicated space where the two systems work together seamlessly, enabling bidirectional data sharing. In this setup, SAP BDC Connect assigns resources and puts the right settings in place—so your external systems are fully prepared, integrated with SAP BDC and ready to run advanced data processes without extra hassle. 

Curious how it all comes together? Grab a coffee and follow along with the how-to video below—I’ll walk you through each step of the provisioning process.

 

This video was made in an internal SAP test system.

I hope this walkthrough made the process clearer and saved you some time. Setting up SAP BDC with Databricks doesn’t have to be overwhelming—once you know the steps, it’s actually pretty straightforward. If you run into questions along the way, don’t hesitate to revisit the video or check the SAP Business Data Cloud Connect documentation for extra details. As always, we're here to help you.

If you liked reading this post, feel free to share it with your colleagues. Also, I invite you to follow my profile and leave a comment or a question. Remember to follow the SAP Business Data Cloud tag to get the latest news available.

All the best,

Eduardo

entry.title: Re: Parallel accounting activation in future
entry.content:
Hello @ai_takahashi 

Recommendation

J62 – Asset Accounting (FI-AA): Activate any fixed assets now for initial setup. J62 serves as the core FI-AA foundation and is included as a standard scope item for Public Cloud. Delaying activation typically increases migration and testing efforts. SAP Help Portal-Asset Accounting-Scope Items for Asset Accounting

1GB – Asset Accounting for Group Ledger (IFRS): Activate with J62 if IFRS ledger reporting for assets is needed. 1GB covers IFRS/group ledger FI-AA scope. If not needed now, defer 1GB, but plan your parallel ledger and depreciation areas to prevent rework.

Note on 1GA: 1GA covers the G/L close for the IFRS group ledger; it does not replace FI-AA. Asset-level IFRS valuations are linked to 1GB, not 1GA. SAP Support Portal-3530183 - Assigning Accounting Principles to Ledgers and Company Codes in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: Details on Configuration in General Ledger Accounting and Asset Accounting

If you defer a 1GB post go-live, do it via a change project and (if required) raise a scope item activation request for component XX-S4C-OPR-SRV. SAP Support Portal-3045179 - Request to activate scope item

Let me know if you need further information

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Challenges in Modify Batch Details at Sub-Item Level...
entry.content:
Hello @ashoktirumalasetti30 

Thank you for your question

There is no released BAdI to clear or modify delivery batch-split sub-items at save/PGI time in public cloud. However, SAP supports a configuration.

  • You can set up Batch Determination in deliveries so that once the required quantity is covered, the system will not propose additional batches
  • You can also assign the search procedure to the delivery item category and test it from the Manage Outbound Deliveries.
  • If your user created extra splits manually, ensure you re-run batch determination in the item; the system should propose only what is needed you will not have a clear sub-item to pass PGI.

If you are on EWM, ensure you use stock removal strategies and picking rules. This will ensure no batches over-picking instead of trying to clear them programmatically.

Have a look at Definition of a Batch Search Strategy, Batch Determination for Deliveries & Extensibility for more details.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Unlocking AI: Understanding Joule and SAP Business AI from Strategy to Activation
entry.content:
As organizations look to harness the power of Artificial Intelligence (AI) to drive transformation, SAP Business AI stands at the forefront - embedding intelligence directly into business processes to deliver smarter decisions and measurable outcomes.

From finance and supply chain to HR, procurement, and customer experience, SAP Business AI infuses trusted, relevant, and responsible AI across every process - ensuring each insight is contextual, every recommendation actionable, and every outcome aligned with enterprise goals.

Whether leveraging Joule, SAP’s AI copilot, or AI-embedded scenarios across your SAP applications, your path to becoming an intelligent and sustainable enterprise begins with understanding and activating SAP’s Business AI capabilities.

To help you unlock this value faster, we’re launching a new Expert-Guided Implementation (EGI): 

Unlocking AI: Joule and SAP Business AI from Strategy to Activation

This multi-day, expert-led workshop is designed to help you and your team unlock the full potential of Joule and SAP Business AI across your SAP landscape. Guided by SAP experts, you’ll explore how to translate strategy into execution with practical exercises, live demonstrations, and activation guidance.

Workshop Schedule

To accommodate global participants, this session will be offered in two time zones:

  • October 20–22, 2025 | 10:00am–12:00pm EMEA time zone

  • November 3–5, 2025 | 10:00am –12:00pm NY time zone


What You’ll Learn

Through this EGI, participants will gain hands-on experience and actionable knowledge in:

  • SAP Business AI Strategy & Foundation - Understand SAP’s AI vision, architecture, and trusted approach to delivering responsible, embedded intelligence
  • Commercial Model & AI Units - Learn how to navigate Base vs Premium models, the AI Feature Catalog, and use the AI Estimator to plan your adoption journey
  • Joule – AI Built for Business - Explore Joule’s unified architecture, roadmap, and capabilities across Joule for Business, Joule for Developers, and Joule for Consultants
  • S/4HANA AI & ML Capabilities - Experience ISLM in action through AI/ML demo use cases designed to enhance decision-making and process automation
  • SAP BTP AI & ML Capabilities - Discover how BTP AI Foundation, Document AI, AI Services, AI Core, and AI Launchpad can help you extend and scale innovation
  • Joule Activation & Prerequisites - Gain a clear view of activation steps, prerequisites, and how to extend Joule with Document Grounding, Joule Studio, and AI Agents

Why Attend

This workshop goes beyond theory—it’s interactive, practical, and guided by SAP experts. By the end, you’ll have:

  • A clear understanding of SAP’s Business AI strategy and product portfolio
  • The ability to activate Joule and deploy AI scenarios across your landscape
  •  Actionable steps to integrate AI and Generative AI into your business workflows
  • Insights into commercial models and AI unit management for smarter planning

Whether you’re a business leader shaping AI strategy or a technical consultant implementing it, this EGI equips you to bridge the gap between strategy and execution.

How to Register

👉 Register here to secure your spot* today to learn from SAP experts and gain the skills to bring Business AI to life across your enterprise.

entry.title: Re: SAP MDG - Material - Class & characteristics
entry.content:
Hello @pankaj0708 

Thank you for your question

You cannot directly attach a custom F4 to a characteristic in the classification system within the public cloud.

SAP supports the creation of Custom Business Object that holds your parent values, then create a custom field for the parent characterisctics that references the CBO. The system will then generate the F4 from it automatically.

Alternatively, you can build a small Custom Fiori app where the parent field dropdown is created from your custom table through a CDS view or CBO service.

Have a look at Custom Business Objects, Custom Fields and Logic & Key User Extensibility links for more details.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How does the official start date impact employee bene...
entry.content:
In most UAE cases, the official start date for gratuity is tied to the work permit or visa activation date, since that’s when the employee is legally allowed to work and the contract becomes enforceable under labor law.

However, if the contract signing date and visa date are both clearly documented in HR files and payroll records, some companies — especially in SAP setups may use the earlier contract date for internal consistency, provided it aligns with company policy.

For payroll configuration, it’s best to align with what’s recognized by the Ministry of Human Resources and Emiratisation (MOHRE) typically the visa stamping date to avoid disputes later.

entry.title: Re: Is it possible to have value help for custom field ba...
entry.content:
Hello @P00019191 

Yes, S/4HANA Public Cloud supports this feature, but only when your value help comes from a Core Data Services (CDS)–based code list, not a static list.

Static code lists (typed values) are visible to all users and cannot be filtered by authorisation, so everyone sees the same list. SAP Support Portal-3612451 - Custom Fields - Frequently Asked Questions - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

Let me know if you need further information

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit – Migrate Directly from SAP System – Increase flexibility by using Spl
entry.content:
Hi all, 

Have you ever wondered how to create multiple entries in a target parameter of the target API using just one source table entry? Have you ever had the requirement to migrate one material to multiple plants although the material is only available in one plant in your source SAP system?  

With SAP S/4HANA 2025, a new feature is available for the S/4HANA Migration Cockpit called "Split Logic", which can be accessed using the Migration Object Modeler (transaction LTMOM). Note that this feature is only available for the migration approach "Migrate Data Directly from SAP System". 

Usually, one entry is created in the target parameter for each assigned source table entry. Using the "Split Logic" feature, you can define a split for the source table to create multiple entries in the target parameter for each source table entry.  

There are two types of split logic - simple split logic and advanced split logic. You can use simple split logic to create a fixed number of entries in the target parameter for each source table entry. Using the advanced split logic, you have a flexible way of defining the number of splits using rules. 

You have then the possibility to define different field mapping information for each of the so-called "splits". 

Some use cases for split logic include: 

  • Creating multiple entries in the target parameter based on one source entry (for example if you want to create a material in multiple plants, whereas previously the material was only available in one plant in the source system) 
  • Handling more complex migration requirements, for example if data in the source system is stored differently than in the target API. 

 We highly recommend reading our recently published SAP Note 3595079 for more information about this topic. 

 Let us know how you might use the split logic and feel free to comment below!  

  All the best for your project!

entry.title: Re: How to add account assignment columns to PR item tabl...
entry.content:
Hello @Simon__R 

Thank you for your question

Answer to question 1:

There is currently no way to add new columns directly to the item table in the My inbox Purchase Requisition approval task UI. This is because the workflow UI is based on a fixed CDS view that you cannot extend in public cloud.

Answer to question 2:

Yes, you can achieve this through Custom Fields and logic by exposing these fields in the Manage Purchase Requisitions or analytical apps.

Alternatively, you can Build a Custom Task UI that consumes the PR API and joins account assignment data by using CDS Views. Then you can link it to your custom workflow scenario.

 

Consult the following links for more insights.

entry.title: Re: Automatically Align Document, Pricing, and Billing Da...
entry.content:
Hello @Katharinam 

Please note that the Document Date, Pricing Date and Billing Date are not automatically synchronised. This is because they are all standard fields at the sales order header level.

Similar to your other question, the in-app extensibility will also do this. The steps below are necessary:

  1. Go to Custom Fields and Logic --> Sales Document.
  2. Then you need to implement the Define Field Value for Sales Document BAdI.
  3. In your logic, copy the Document Date value to the pricing date and billing date whenever the order is created or changed.

Optionally, you can make the pricing and billing date fields read-only via Adapt UI, this will ensure they always follow your document date.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Lease accounting (IFRS16) with RE-FX
entry.content:
Hello,

We have a need to migrate legacy contract for Operating Lease into S/4 HANA 2023 version from the legacy system. We do not forsee any issues migrating the contract and the ROU assets with APC, AD and CY Depreciation up to go-live and then link the Contract with the ROU assets migrated using AS91/ABLDT (historical balances). In the migrated Contract, we were able to use condition Type V107 - Net Worth Value Specified. In this case the Classification setting for the Contract Type = Right of Use Approach (Linearization). 

However, when try to use the same approach for Contract Type in which Classification setting is "B - Straight Line Lease (Linearized Committment), it gives the error message "

Error message RECETM234 is raised when confirming the Valuation Rule for Condition Type V107 (Net Worth Value Specified (Legacy Data)".

SAP has called out in the OSS Note 2544232 - Leasing: Handling transition scenarios with "General Remark" that V107 cannot be used for this setting. 

"Note that it is not possible to use the condition valuation property 'Net Worth Value Specified' or 'Net Worth Value Specified (Legacy Data)' in connection with a balance-sheet valuation rule of the classification B 'Straight-Line Lease (Linearized Commitment)'. The special way in which the depreciation is calculated for valuation classification B prohibits the use of a predefined asset because the leasing costs (total of the payments) are offset over the leasing term on a linear basis".

Looking for guidance how to migrate such types of Lease Contract and ROU Asset with APC, Acc. Depreciation and CY Depreciation. 

Thanks.

entry.title: Re: The OSS message xxxxx/2025 (not sent to SAP) is not n...
entry.content:
Dear customer,

Deleting a case is not possible (not even by SAP). Refer to KBA 2655109. 

For the Draft cases (with status 'not sent to SAP'), they can be deleted on customer side, but only the super user or the case reporter can delete it. 

Cloud and User Administrators cannot delete draft cases created by other S-users at this time.

Kindly refer to KBA 2594949 - How to delete a draft case - SAP for Me for more detailed information. 

Thanks and regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: Sample report to fix BEGDA/ENDDA of P-CP/CP-P relationship in table HRP1001
entry.content:
Below is an example of a custom report (Provided by SAP Note 2058445) that modifies the start date of the A/B209 relationship in table HRP1001 from '00.00.0000' to the actual 'hiring date.'

******************************

DATA: ls_hrpersonee TYPE hrpersonee_s,
      lt_pernr      TYPE pernr_tab,
      lv_hiredate   TYPE begda,
      lv_initial    TYPE begda,
      lv_count      TYPE i,
      lv_plvar      TYPE plvar.

FIELD-SYMBOLS: <lv_pernr> TYPE pernr_d.

**************
PARAMETERS p_test TYPE boole_d DEFAULT 'X'.

CALL FUNCTION 'RH_GET_ACTIVE_WF_PLVAR'
  IMPORTING
    act_plvar = lv_plvar.
CLEAR lv_initial.
SELECT objid FROM hrp1001 INTO TABLE lt_pernr
                          WHERE otype = 'P'
                            AND plvar = lv_plvar
                            AND rsign = 'A'
                            AND relat = '209'
                            AND istat = '1'
                            AND begda = lv_initial.

LOOP AT lt_pernr ASSIGNING <lv_pernr>.
  IF p_test = space.
    CALL FUNCTION 'RP_GET_HIRE_DATE'
      EXPORTING
        persnr          = <lv_pernr>
        check_infotypes = '0000'
      IMPORTING
        hiredate        = lv_hiredate.
    IF lv_hiredate IS INITIAL.
      CONTINUE.
    ENDIF.

    "A209 P->CP
    UPDATE hrp1001 SET begda = lv_hiredate
                   WHERE otype = 'P'
                     AND objid = <lv_pernr>
                     AND plvar = lv_plvar
                     AND rsign = 'A'
                     AND relat = '209'
                     AND istat = '1'
                     AND begda = lv_initial.
    "B209 CP->P
    UPDATE hrp1001 SET begda = lv_hiredate
               WHERE otype = 'CP'
                 AND plvar = lv_plvar
                 AND rsign = 'B'
                 AND relat = '209'
                 AND istat = '1'
                 AND begda = lv_initial
                 AND sobid = <lv_pernr>.
  ENDIF.
  lv_count = lv_count + 1.
ENDLOOP.

IF sy-subrc = 0.
  WRITE: / 'Anzahl inkonsistenter Datensätze: ', lv_count.
  IF p_test = space.
    COMMIT WORK.
  ENDIF.
ELSE.
  WRITE: / 'Keine inkonsistenten Datensätze gefunden'.
ENDIF.

*******************************

If you need to adjust the end date of the A/B209 relationship or want to change the start date from another incorrect date to the correct 'hiring date,' you can refer to the sample code provided and develop your own custom report.

By tailoring such reports, you can ensure accurate and consistent HR data management across your SAP environment.

entry.title: How to Connect to SAP IBP from SAP Datasphere using OData
entry.content:
How to Connect to the SAP IBP System from SAP Datasphere using OData APIs

Use case - In our organization, we use IBP mainly for Demand Planning and Supply Planning. We needed some reporting to track the forecast accuracy, monitoring KPIs and especially the exception management. Inorder to achieve this, we wanted to store the snapshot of IBP data in our datasphere. 

SAP Datasphere doesnt have a direct connection to SAP IBP and we also cannot use the API which is used for SAP Analytics Cloud (/odata/IBP/EXTRACT_ODATA_SRV). So, to solve this, we used the below steps. 

We can use the following APIs based on our use case.

  • Master Data: /IBP/MASTER_DATA_API_SRV

  • Key Figures: /IBP/PLANNING_DATA_API_SRV

Please follow the steps outlined below:

Part 1 – IBP Configuration

  1. Create a Communication User within the IBP system. This user ID will be required when configuring the OData connection in Datasphere.
  2. Navigate to Communication Arrangement and identify the scenario SAP_COM_0720.
  3. Under Inbound Communications, assign the newly created communication user.
  4. Assign a reference business user under Corresponding Business User.

(Ensure that the reference business user is granted all necessary permissions to access relevant IBP data)

 

 

Part 2 – Datasphere

  1. Create a Generic OData connection.
  2. Go to Connections → New, select Generic OData.
    • Enter the service URL (e.g., .../ PLANNING_DATA_API_SRV), and upload the server certificate if required (only for remote table and replication flows; not needed for data flows).
  3. Set Version to V2.
  4. Set Authentication Type to Username and Password, using the new communication user ID and password from IBP.

 

Part 3 – Creating the data flow in datasphere.

  1. Go to data builder and create a new data flow.
  2. Go to source and select the right connection – This should show the list of planning areas that are visible based on the authorization.
  3. Select the desired planning area and hit add selection - Now you should see the source node in your data flow.
  4. Under OData parameters, create a select parameter line and type in the required dimensions – use the exact technical names of the field from the source node.

5. Under Source filters, input the required Unit of Measure or other mandatory inputs for your planning area. (Also, include other filters based on your need)

 

6. Add a target table to your data flow or do the necessary transformations based on your needs.

Once you’ve completed the configuration steps outlined above, you’ll be able to seamlessly preview and pull data from your planning area into SAP Datasphere. This ensures that your data integration is both efficient and secure, empowering you to make the most of your SAP IBP and Datasphere environments. Happy data modeling!

entry.title: Step-by-Step: Implementing Generative AI with SAP HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Introduction:

This blog walks through building an AI Sales Assistant on SAP HANA Cloud calculation views. The assistant enables users to ask natural-language questions such as “Which product category had the highest sales in Q2?” and receive contextual answers generated directly from enterprise data.

The solution uses the Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) pattern, where sales transactions stored in HANA are enriched with embeddings and combined with a Large Language Model (LLM) to deliver precise, business-aware responses. This approach extends the analytical power of HANA Cloud with conversational intelligence- effectively bringing AI integration to your calculation views without moving the data out of HANA.

We’ll cover the concepts, high-level architecture, and detailed implementation steps so you can replicate this setup on your own HANA Cloud system and make the most of your existing calculation views.

High Level Architecture:

Key Concepts:

Retrieval-Augmented Generation:

It’s an AI pattern where a language model (like GPT) is not used in isolation, but is “augmented” with external knowledge retrieved from a database or document store.

It has two main steps:

  1. Retrieval – Find the most relevant documents/data from a knowledge source (e.g., database, embeddings index, vector store).

  2. Generation – Pass both the retrieved data + the user’s query into the LLM so the response is grounded in actual facts instead of just relying on the LLM’s training data.

SAP HANA Cloud:
The foundation of this project is SAP HANA Cloud. HANA calculation view serves as the source for the RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) application. With the new HANA Cloud Vector Engine, we can now store and query embeddings directly inside HANA eliminating the need for external vector databases. For this setup, we create a dedicated embeddings table to persist vector representations of the sales data.

Flask API:
For the backend, I used Flask, a lightweight Python web framework.Flask allows Python code to be exposed as REST APIs or lightweight web applications. In this project, the Flask API connects to the HANA calculation view, retrieves data, and interacts with the OpenAI API. OpenAI generates embeddings for the data, which are then stored in the embeddings table in HANA Cloud. The same API also handles user prompts: it takes queries from the frontend, searches the embeddings table, and returns contextual answers. 

Streamlit:
The frontend is built with Streamlit, a Python framework for creating simple yet powerful user interfaces. It provides a chat-like interface where users can enter questions. The prompts are passed to the Flask API, which handles retrieval and reasoning. While Streamlit makes prototyping easy, this frontend could also be replaced with SAP Fiori or any Web frontend.

Implementation steps:

Let’s see step by step on how to develop this framework for existing calculation views.

Prerequisites: Python 3.9+, BAS environment, CF CLI, HANA DB instance, OpenAI API key.

  1. I have two projects in BAS: one containing the HANA calculation views, and the other containing the Flask backend (referred to as the Flask app). Below is the output of the calculation view.

        2.We need to convert the hana data into embeddings and store them in HANA tables. Create embeddings table in HANA cloud. Below is the sql for that. 

CREATE TABLE SALES_EMBEDDINGS (
    TRANSACTION_ID NVARCHAR(50),
    TEXT NVARCHAR(5000),
    EMBEDDING REAL_VECTOR(1536)
);

       3. To generate embeddings using a LLM we need access. In my case i have used LLM from Open AI. Create an account in Open AI and register for Open API key.

       4. Create a python file (eg : generate_embeddings.py) in your flask project to generate embeddings based on your calculation view data and store in HANA cloud table created above. Have your credentials in the env file for testing. Make sure your BAS dev space is in the same region as your HANA cloud instance otherwise connection fails.  This step makes sure we are able to connect to HANA convert calculation view(CV) data into text and generate embeddings for it. Run this file separately and see if data is inserted into HANA cloud table.

import os
from hdbcli import dbapi
from openai import OpenAI
from dotenv import load_dotenv

# Load environment variables
load_dotenv()

# OpenAI client
client = OpenAI(api_key=os.getenv("OPENAI_API_KEY"))

# Connect to SAP HANA Cloud
conn = dbapi.connect(
    address=os.getenv("HANA_HOST"),   # e.g. yourhana.hana.prod-us10.hanacloud.ondemand.com
    port=int(os.getenv("HANA_PORT", "443")),
    user=os.getenv("HANA_USER"),
    password=os.getenv("HANA_PASSWORD")
)

cursor = conn.cursor()

# Fetch sales transactions
cursor.execute("""
    SELECT TRANSACTION_ID, REGION, PRODUCT, SALES_AMOUNT, SALE_DATE 
    FROM schema name."cv_sales_test"
""")
rows = cursor.fetchall()

# 5. Generate embeddings and insert into HANA
for row in rows:
    transaction_id, region, product, sales_amount, sales_date = row
    text = f"Transaction {transaction_id} in {region} sold {product} for {sales_amount} on {sales_date}"

    embedding = client.embeddings.create(
        model="text-embedding-3-small",
        input=text
    ).data[0].embedding

    cursor.execute("""
        INSERT INTO "schemaname"."SALES_EMBEDDINGS" (TRANSACTION_ID, TEXT, EMBEDDING)
        VALUES (?, ?, ?)
    """, (transaction_id, text, embedding))

conn.commit()
cursor.close()
conn.close()

print("Embeddings inserted into SALES_EMBEDDINGS table in HANA Cloud.")

Sales embeddings table output:

       5. Now let's implement RAG on embeddings. Create a new file for RAG query code. This function connects to HANA cloud and fetches stored vector representations of the transactions. The user's question is passed to OpenAI embeddings API and question is converted into numerical vector. We compute cosine similarity between the query embedding and stored transaction embeddings. The top results are combined with the user’s original question to form a prompt, which is then sent to the LLM to generate a contextual answer.

import os
import json
import struct
import numpy as np
from hdbcli import dbapi
from openai import OpenAI
from sklearn.metrics.pairwise import cosine_similarity
from dotenv import load_dotenv

load_dotenv()


# --------------------------
# Get HANA credentials (VCAP aware)
# --------------------------
def get_hana_credentials(debug=False):
    vcap_services = os.environ.get("VCAP_SERVICES")
    if vcap_services:
        try:
            vcap = json.loads(vcap_services)
            for key in vcap:
                if "hana" in key.lower():  # find any hana service
                    creds = vcap[key][0]["credentials"]
                    if debug:
                        print("Found HANA credentials from VCAP_SERVICES:", creds)
                    return {
                        "host": creds.get("host"),
                        "port": creds.get("port"),
                        "user": creds.get("user"),
                        "password": creds.get("password")
                    }
        except Exception as e:
            if debug:
                print("Error parsing VCAP_SERVICES:", e)

    # fallback to env vars
    creds = {
        "host": os.environ.get("HANA_HOST"),
        "port": os.environ.get("HANA_PORT"),
        "user": os.environ.get("HANA_USER"),
        "password": os.environ.get("HANA_PASSWORD")
    }
    if debug:
        print("Using HANA credentials from environment variables:", creds)
    return creds

# --------------------------
# Run RAG query
# --------------------------

def run_rag_query(user_query, top_k=5, debug=False):

    openai_api_key = os.environ.get("OPENAI_API_KEY")
    if not openai_api_key:
        raise Exception("OPENAI_API_KEY environment variable not set")
    openai_client = OpenAI(api_key=openai_api_key)

    hana_creds = get_hana_credentials(debug=debug)
   
    conn = None
    cursor = None
    try:
        conn = dbapi.connect(
            address=hana_creds["host"],
            port=int(hana_creds["port"]),
            user=hana_creds["user"],
            password=hana_creds["password"]
        )
        cursor = conn.cursor()

        # Fetch embeddings from HANA
        cursor.execute('SELECT TRANSACTION_ID, TEXT, EMBEDDING FROM "schemaname"."SALES_EMBEDDINGS"')
        rows = cursor.fetchall()

        if not rows:
            context = "No transactions available."
        else:
            # Compute query embedding
            embedding_resp = openai_client.embeddings.create(
                model="text-embedding-3-small",
                input=user_query
            )
            query_embedding = np.array(embedding_resp.data[0].embedding, dtype=np.float32)
            query_dim = len(query_embedding)

            texts, embedding_list = [], []
            for row in rows:
                text = row[1]
                blob = row[2]
                if len(blob) < query_dim * 4:
                    continue
                embedding = np.array(struct.unpack('f' * query_dim, blob[:query_dim*4]), dtype=np.float32)
                texts.append(text)
                embedding_list.append(embedding)

            if not embedding_list:
                context = "No valid transactions found."
            else:
                similarities = [cosine_similarity(query_embedding.reshape(1, -1), e.reshape(1, -1))[0][0] for e in embedding_list]
                top_indices = np.argsort(similarities)[-top_k:][::-1]
                context = "\n".join([texts[i] for i in top_indices])

        # GPT completion: summarize transactions
        prompt = f"""
You are a helpful sales analyst assistant.
Based on the following transactions:

{context}

Answer the user's question in **natural language**, summarizing key insights if possible.
Question: {user_query}
Please keep your answer concise.
"""

        response = openai_client.chat.completions.create(
            model="gpt-4o-mini",
            messages=[{"role": "user", "content": prompt}]
        )

        return response.choices[0].message.content.strip()

    except Exception as e:
        return f"Error in run_rag_query: {str(e)}"

    finally:
        if cursor:
            cursor.close()
        if conn:
            conn.close()

 

       6.  Wrap the above RAG query code in a function and use it in Flask. Install Flask if not already available. Now Flask API is directly using RAG logic. Frontend application can call this API and get a response. Ensure the Flask API works locally and returns expected results before deploying to Cloud Foundry.

pip install flask

 

from flask import Flask, request, jsonify
from hdbcli import dbapi
from openai import OpenAI
import numpy as np
import struct
import os
import json
from sklearn.metrics.pairwise import cosine_similarity as sk_cos_sim
from dotenv import load_dotenv

load_dotenv()

app = Flask(__name__)

# --------------------------
# Cosine similarity
# --------------------------
def cosine_similarity(a, b):
    norm_a = np.linalg.norm(a)
    norm_b = np.linalg.norm(b)
    if norm_a == 0 or norm_b == 0:
        return -1
    return np.dot(a, b) / (norm_a * norm_b)

# --------------------------
# Get HANA credentials
# --------------------------
def get_hana_credentials():
    vcap_services = os.environ.get("VCAP_SERVICES")
    if vcap_services:
        try:
            vcap = json.loads(vcap_services)

            # Look for a service whose name includes "hana"
            for service_name, service_defs in vcap.items():
                if service_name.lower() == "hdi_db":
                    creds = service_defs[0]["credentials"]
                    host = creds.get("host")
                    port = creds.get("port")
                    user = creds.get("user")
                    password = creds.get("password")

                    if host and port and user and password:
                        print(f"Using HANA service from VCAP: {service_name}")
                        return {
                            "host": host,
                            "port": port,
                            "user": user,
                            "password": password
                        }
                    else:
                        print(f"HANA service in VCAP missing user/password. Falling back to manual env vars.")

        except Exception as e:
            print(f"Failed to parse VCAP_SERVICES: {e}")

    # Fallback to manual env vars
    print("Using manual HANA_* environment variables")
    return {
        "host": os.environ.get("HANA_HOST"),
        "port": os.environ.get("HANA_PORT"),
        "user": os.environ.get("HANA_USER"),
        "password": os.environ.get("HANA_PASSWORD")
    }

# --------------------------
# RAG query
# --------------------------
#
# " Your RAG Query here"

# --------------------------
# Health check route
# --------------------------
@app.route("/")
def index():
    return "Flask API is running!"

# --------------------------
# Query route
# --------------------------
@app.route("/query", methods=["POST"])
def query_rag_route():
    data = request.get_json()
    user_query = data.get("query", "")
    if not user_query:
        return jsonify({"error": "Query missing"}), 400

    # Run RAG query
    results = run_rag_query(user_query, top_k=5, debug=False)

    # Return in a format that Streamlit expects
    return jsonify({"results": results})

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.run(debug=True, host="0.0.0.0", port=int(os.environ.get("PORT", 5000)))

Once you run flask API code ,it will start REST API server. It should return "Flask API is running".

http://<your-BAS-workspace-url>:5000/query

        7. Deploy the Flask app on SAP BTP Cloud Foundry and you will see a URL assigned. Deploying it on cloud foundry frees the dependency on BAS dev space and our frontend app can always call the Flask API. Bind it to the HANA service instance so that cloud foundry injects credentials into the app's environment (VCAP_SERVICES) so the running code can connect to HANA. This makes sure our Flask API will have HANA credentials at runtime. After binding check environment and logs.

Check for services and push your app to CF.

cf services
cf push "app name" -f manifest.yml

For binding app to HANA service:

cf bind-service "app name" "hana service"
cf restage "app name"

Verify environment and logs

cf env "your app name"
cf logs "your app name" --recent

Test it using curl. See the response in results section.

       8. For UI, I have implemented using streamlit on my local machine. In Command line run 'pip install streamlit requests' . Run the program file that contains the code. 

Your browser will open at :

http://localhost:8501

 

Type in any question and it will return a contextual response like below.

Key Advantages:

Leverage Existing SAP Data assets- Reuse of existing HDI Containers and calculation views.

Secured and Enabled -  Access to HANA data remains within the SAP security framework.

Scalable and extensible - The architecture can support multiple use cases like Finance, HR, and Logistics.

Enhanced insights - Combines structured data retrieval with natural-language summarization.

Conclusion:

By integrating SAP HANA Cloud with a Large Language Model using the Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) approach, we’ve transformed standard calculation views into an AI-powered sales assistant . This demonstrates how modern AI capabilities can be layered on top of established enterprise data systems, opening the door to smarter, faster, and more interactive business decision-making.

Thank you,

Saravanan Chinnaswamy.

entry.title: Steps to Configure AIF for Complex Structure File Data with Multiple Header-Item in Flat File
entry.content:
In this blog I'd like to share the Steps of integrating complex structured file data into SAP systems to dealing with nested formats like header-item-schedule line relationships.  Application Integration Framework (AIF) provides a powerful and flexible solution to address these challenges. By leveraging AIF’s capabilities, such as custom DDIC structures, composite data modeling, and robust file adapter configurations—organizations can streamline their file-based integrations, reduce custom coding efforts, and improve data accuracy. This guide walked through the essential steps to configure AIF for such scenarios, empowering SAP developers to build scalable and maintainable interfaces for enterprise data exchange.

Introduction:

In modern enterprise integration scenarios, organizations often exchange file-based data that includes multiple layers of structured information—typically comprising header records and their associated item records. Accurately processing these complex file formats is vital to ensure seamless and reliable data exchange between systems.

SAP’s Application Integration Framework (AIF) offers a comprehensive solution for managing such integrations. It supports the definition and handling of complex data structures, including nested models where each header can be linked to multiple item records. This capability enables flexible interface design and robust data validation, making AIF an ideal choice for processing structured file content in SAP environments.

By utilizing AIF’s features, organizations can streamline file-based integrations and enhance data consistency across systems.

Problem Description

In enterprise integrations, companies often receive files from external systems that contain structured data—like sales orders with headers and related item details. These files can be complex, with multiple layers of information that need to be grouped and processed correctly.

Standard file processing in SAP can struggle with this kind of nested data. Common issues include:

  • Difficulty linking items to the correct headers
  • Risk of data mismatches
  • Complicated custom code for parsing and validation
  • Limited tools for tracking and fixing errors

SAP Application Integration Framework (AIF) helps solve these problems by supporting complex data structures. It allows headers to be connected to multiple items and provides tools for parsing, validating, and monitoring the data. However, setting up AIF for this requires careful planning and configuration to ensure everything works smoothly.

How does it work?

You need to perform the following steps to create an inbound file interface:

  1. Create the RAW structures for the interface
  2. Develop the interface
  3. Configure the file adapter settings for your interface
  4. Upload File
  5. Check Monitoring and Error Handling transaction

The following example will describe step-by-step how to Configure AIF for Complex File Data with Multiple Header-Item in Flat File

Simple example of a Sales Order creation in SAP, showing how the Header, Item, and Schedule Line levels are organized

Prepare the Flat File (CSV Format)

Create a .csv file using a pipe (|) as the delimiter. Here's a simple structure:

In order to execute this example, we require a file containing some test data and corresponding structures.

Explanation:

  • HEAD = Header line (Sales Order Number, Date, Customer, Sales Org, Currency)
  • ITEM = Item line (Item Number, Material, Material Description, Quantity, Price)
  • SCHD = Schedule line (Item Number, Schedule Line Item, Delivery Date, Quantity)

1. Create Raw Structures for the interface

🔧 Step 1: Create DDIC Structures

1.1 Header Structure – YAIF_ORDER_HDR

Field Name

Data Element

Description

ORDER_NO

VBELN

Sales Order Number

ORDER_DATE

AUDAT

Document Date

CUSTOMER_ID

KUNNR

Customer Number

VKORG

VKORG

Sales Organization

CURRENCY

WAERS

Currency

1.2 Item Structure – YAIF_ORDER_ITEM

Field Name

Data Element

Description

ITEM_NO

POSNR

Item Number

MATNR

MATNR

Material Number

MAKTX

MAKTX

Material Description

MENGE

MENGE_D

Quantity

AMOUNT

NETPR

Price

1.3 Schedule Line Structure – YAIF_ORDER_SCHEDULE_LINE

Field Name

Data Element

Description

POSNR

POSNR

Item Number

ETENR

ETENR

Schedule Line Number

DELIVERY_DATE

EDATU

Delivery Date

BMENG

BMENG

Delivery Quantity

 

📦 Step 2: Create Table Types

2.1 Item Table Type – YAIF_ORDER_ITEM_TT

  • Line Type: YAIF_ORDER_ITEM

2.2 Schedule Line Table Type – YAIF_ORDER_SCHEDULE_LINE_TT

  • Line Type: YAIF_ORDER_SCHEDULE_LINE

 🧩 Step 3: Create Composite Structure

3.1 Detail Structure – YAIF_ORDER_DTL

Field Name

Type

Description

HEADER

YAIF_ORDER_HDR

Header Structure

ITEM

YAIF_ORDER_ITEM_TT

Table of Items

SCHEDULE_LINE

YAIF_ORDER_SCHEDULE_LINE_TT

Table of Schedule Lines

3.2 Table Type – YAIF_ORDER_DTL_TT

  • Line Type: YAIF_ORDER_DTL

3.3 RAW Structure – YAIF_ORDER_DTL_S

Create the RAW structure for the interface. The structure contains only one component named

  • Component Name: ORDER
  • Component Type: YAIF_ORDER_DTL_TT

 2. Develop the interface

🚀 Step 4: Configure AIF Interface

4.1 Define Namespace

  • Use transaction /AIF/CUST

Click->Define namespace (e.g. YSALE)

4.2 Define Interfaces

Click->Define Interface

 

4.3 Specify Interface Engines    

  • Assign the SAP Application Engine

Click->Additional Interface Properties->Specify Interface Engines

4.4 Assign Source Structure Line

Click->Define Structure Mappings

4.4.2 Assign Destination Structure

Select source structure line->Click->Assign Destination Sturcture

4.4.3 Assign Actions

  • Create an action (e.g. SALE_CREATE)

Click->Assign Action

Click Enter on Action to create the action is action is not created

Click->Define Function ( To assign Function Module )

Double-click to create the Function Module that processes the data if not created

Navigate into the new function module by double clicking the name. In the function module call the follow up processing by inserting the coding displayed below:

 

 

*// Sample Logic
 CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_CUSTOMER_CREATE
  EXPORTING
    customer_data = CURR-HEADER
    customer_item = CURR-ITEM
    schedule_line = CURR-SCHEDULE_LINE
  TABLES
    return = return_tab.

 

 

Save and activate the function module.

3. Configure the file adapter settings for your interface

Click-> System Configuration->Configure File Adapter

  • File Type (ASC or BINARY)
  • File Content (Flat Structure, Complex Structure, XML, USER, XSLX )
  • Text Type (Fix char, Special Character Separator)
  • Offset Type Det Val (To Identify the record type from where it will start i.e HEAD, ITEM, SCHD line Details to prepare the data structure dynamically)
  • Length Type Det Val (Length of identity record type in i.e in our case first 4 character of new line)
  • Del Deter Val (True means ignore 1st Field separator immediately after the Det Value)

Leading Type (If we mark the record type as 'true', it means a new record will start from the file)

4. Upload File

The final step is to select and upload the file. The AIF File Upload can be found in the SAP Menu under SAP Menu -> Cross-Application Components --> SAP Application Interface Framework --> File Upload (or directly via transaction /AIF/LFA_UPLOAD_FILE).

Select your File Adapter Configuration (Config. Namespace and Config ID created in step 3). In section Upload from select the path where your file is stored.

Press executes.

5. Check Monitoring and Error Handling transaction

You will be forwarded to a log view where the log messages which have occurred during upload through below T-Code.

  • T-Code : /AIF/ERR ,  /AIF/IFMON

Conclusion

SAP’s Application Integration Framework (AIF) simplifies the integration of complex, structured file data by supporting nested formats like header-item-schedule line relationships. Through custom structures, composite modeling, and flexible configuration, AIF enables scalable, maintainable, and accurate file-based interfaces—reducing custom code and improving data reliability across systems.

Key Benefits of Using AIF for Complex File Integration

  • ✅ Reduced Custom Coding: Leverage AIF’s configuration-driven approach to minimize manual parsing and validation logic.
  • ✅ Support for Nested Structures: Easily model and process multi-level data like headers, items, and schedule lines.
  • ✅ Improved Data Accuracy: Built-in validation and mapping tools help ensure consistent and reliable data processing.
  • ✅ Enhanced Monitoring & Error Handling: AIF provides robust tools for tracking, logging, and resolving integration issues.
  • ✅ Scalable Interface Design: Composite structures and reusable components make it easier to extend and maintain interfaces.

entry.title: Re: Authentification required to access the ATO service
entry.content:
It seems like Basic Authentification is not the correct authenfication type to be used. The correct authentification type to be used here is SAML Assertion with the following destination details.

destination:
 
  Name: "S4H_SA"
  Type: "HTTP"
  Description: "SAML Assertion Destination to SAP S/4HANA Cloud system"
  URL: "https://myxxxxx-api.s4hana.cloud.sap"
  ProxyType: "Internet"
  Authentication: "SAMLAssertion"
  authnContextClassRef: "urn:oasis:names:tc:SAML:2.0:ac:classes:PreviousSession"
  audience: "https://myxxxxxx.s4hana.cloud.sap"
  clientKey: "<removed>"
  skipUserAttributesPrefixInSAMLAttributes: "false"
  includeSigningCertificateInSAMLAssertion: "false"
  skipUserUuidInSAMLAttributes: "false"
  HTML5.DynamicDestination: "true"
  HTML5.Timeout: "60000"
  WebIDEEnabled: "true"
  WebIDEUsage: "odata_abap,dev_abap"
  WebIDESystem: "S4HPC"
  sap-client: "080"
  sap-platform: "ABAP"
  nameIdFormat: "urn:oasis:names:tc:SAML:1.1:nameid-format:emailAddress"
 
Please ensure you have configured everything mentioned here:https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/abap-custom-ui-bas-connect-s4hc.html

entry.title: What is new in S/4HANA Manufacturing for Production Engineering & Operations (PEO) in 2025 FPS0
entry.content:
What is new in S/4HANA Manufacturing for Production Engineering & Operations (PEO) in 2025 FPS0

The 2025 release of SAP S/4HANA Manufacturing for production engineering and operations (PEO) offers significant enhancements that streamline manufacturing processes, improve operational flexibility, and enhance user experience across the production lifecycle. This blog post explores the key innovations in the areas of product rework capabilities, production engineering efficiency, flexible production operations, and extensibility improvements.

 

Product Rework

PEO now enables comprehensive rework capabilities for products at any time after completion of their production order, including externally procured products. This functionality allows replacement of defective or degraded components identified for completed orders, as well as repairs or maintenance on products that have been in storage or returned from the field. The system provides the same level of traceability for product rework orders as for standard shop floor orders, ensuring complete visibility throughout the process.

 

For more information, see Performing Product Rework | SAP Help Portal.

Production Engineering Efficiency

Automatic Plan-as-Designed with Phantom Flattening

The shop floor BOM in PEO does not expect phantom assemblies. But many customers define mBOMs in PLM systems with phantom assemblies. Using this new capability in PEO, the upstream PLM system can now send mBOMs with phantom assemblies to PEO, which are then automatically processed to create shop floor BOM by doing automated plan-as-design with phantom flattening. Shop floor BOM is created as a mirror of the incoming mBOM but if phantom assemblies are found, they are automatically flattened. The phantom hierarchy information is available for production engineer while working with shop floor routing management and also for production worker while using Perform Work Apps.

Business benefits include:

  • Valuable information on phantom hierarchies is not lost
  • Huge time savings when combined with workflow automation

For more information, see Automatic Plan-As-Designed | SAP Help Portal.

Work Instructions: Usability Improvements

Usability has been improved in both interactive and non-interactive work instructions. When adding references to inspection characteristics and PRTs, you can now add multiple references in one step. Multiple selection is also now supported when you add document links.

 

 

In addition, logical components can now be cross-referenced in work instructions.

For more information, see How to Maintain Work Instructions for Operation Activities | SAP Help Portal.

Manage Production Model: Support for Unitized Products

The Manage Production Models - Materials app now enables you to create and manage production models for unitized products. You can define production models at unit level to support different customer requirements, thereby optimizing your production planning.

A Parameter Effectivity section has been added to the details page for components, operations, and operation activities.

 

You can also release a production model version for a subset of the MBOM effectivity range.

 

For more information, see Manage Production Model – Materials | SAP Help Portal.

 

Manage Production Model: Create Sales-Order-Specific BOM and Routing for Non-Configurable Products

 


The Manage Production Models - Engineer-to-Order app now supports the creation of ETO production models for non-configurable materials such as material type HALB (Semifinished Product) or FERT (Finished Product). A simple guided procedure takes users through the steps to create an ETO production model using a sales order for a non-configurable material and engineer it further by adding components and production steps. This enables meeting special customer requirements even when the material in the sales order is not configurable.

For more information, see Manage Production Model – Engineer-to-Order | SAP Help Portal.

 

Assign Documents to Operations in Routings

You can now assign documents at operation level in shop floor routings. Documents applicable to all operation activities of a specific operation now only need to be assigned once, saving time and effort while eliminating the risk of different and contradictory information being displayed for each operation activity.

 

For more information, see How to Assign Documents to Operations | SAP Help Portal.

Usability Improvements for Shop Floor Routing Template Handling

To allow for easier organization of templates in the folder view, you can now cut a template and paste it at a different position in the structure.

 

When you display the template library, the system automatically filters the list of templates by the production plant of the template that you're editing. This improves performance and usability by reducing the number of templates initially displayed.

 

 

Flexible Production Operations

Perform OA: Usability Improvement for Displaying Documents

In the Perform Operation Activity app, document service control has been replaced by a responsive table to enable file previews within the app. You can now view and download documents and attachments more easily directly within the app.

 

For more information, see Perform Operation Activity | SAP Help Portal.

Parallel Operations Using Parallel Sequences

PEO shop floor routing now supports the creation of sequences for scheduling order operations to run in parallel, like classic routings. A parallel sequence branches from and returns to operations in a reference sequence, with operations in a parallel sequence performed in parallel to operations in the reference sequence. This functionality provides greater process and scheduling flexibility to reduce production time, better utilize resources, and support different manufacturing scenarios.

 

For more information, see How to Create Parallel Sequences | SAP Help Portal.

Alternative Components: Simple Discontinuation

Sometimes prescribed components may be in shortage in shop floor. Using the definition of alternative components, the production engineer can specify alternative components that can be used in such cases. In addition to defining alternative components in BOM, PEO now supports the use of global alternatives defined using simple discontinuation in the material master record.

 

 

Components in the production order can be exchanged for follow-up materials that have been defined using simple discontinuation.

 

This provides more flexibility to replace components in a production order due to defects, stock shortages, or changes in safety requirements without having to update the BOM.

PEO tracks the use of global alternatives in the end-to-end process.

For more information, see Using Global Alternatives | SAP Help Portal.

Extended Quality Check (EQC) Groups

PEO provides the capability of extended quality check (EQC) to enable modelling of regulatory and compliance requirements like first article inspection (FAI), first piece inspection (FPI) or other kind of compliances during production. With EQC production engineer can define conditional operations, operation activities or data collection which generally not applicable for normal production but can be exposed in production orders which requires such extended checks.

PEO has introduced EQC groups to support partial extended quality checks. You define EQC groups in Customizing. Through the assignment of EQC groups to operation activities and inspection characteristics in the shop floor routing, it’s now possible to implement partial extended quality checks. During creation of a shop floor order, EQC groups can be selected, resulting in only those operation activities and inspection characteristics assigned to the selected EQC groups being included in the shop floor order, along with non-EQC-relevant operation activities.

In the example below the production engineer has defined some additional activities tagged with relevant EQC Groups. While creating the order, it can be identified as an order which requires for example in this case ‘Full FAI’ or ‘Partial FAI’ or ‘First Piece’ and depending upon these relevant activities are exposed in the order. Multiple EQC groups can also be assigned to an order.

 

Benefits include:

  • Capability to perform delta or selected quality checks after a full EQC
  • Flexibility to perform partial quality checks across orders if production-related issues prevent a full EQC in a single order

For more information, see Extended Quality Checks | SAP Help Portal.

Qualifications for Buyoff Steps

HR qualifications can now be assigned to each buyoff step in an operation activity.

 


This functionality allows control over who can approve buyoff steps at production completion, ensuring higher quality assurance and improving compliance and audit readiness.

For more information, see How to Assign Buyoffs to Operation Activities | SAP Help Portal.

Retain Serial Number Group Across Operation Activities (Pull Scenario)

 
 

 


Production operators can now copy a serial number group that was completed at the previous operation activity to a new group at the selected operation activity when starting an operation activity in the My Work Queue app (pull scenario).

 

 

This provides more flexibility in copying serial number groups, especially when the production operator performing an operation activity is not the same operator who completed the previous operation activity.

For more information, see How to Copy Serial Number Groups from Previous Operation Activity | SAP Help Portal.

Data Collection: Capture Test Equipment Used

When collecting data in the Perform Operation Activity app, you can now select the test equipment used for a specific inspection characteristic.

 

Benefits of this feature are:

  • Improved traceability and compliance
  • Allows the operator to record unplanned test equipment that was used for the IC

For more information, see How to Record Inspection Characteristics | SAP Help Portal.

Exposing Inspection Method to Production Worker

Inspection methods can now be referenced in shop floor routings. This means that production engineers can:

  • Reference an inspection method when adding an IC.
  • Include the inspection method when referencing ICs in interactive and non-interactive work instructions.

The production operator can navigate to the inspection method from the Perform Operation Activity app, view the details, and then navigate back to the operation activity.

 

For more information, see How to Assign Inspection Method to Inspection Characteristics | SAP Help Portal.

Other New Capabilities

Modernization of Tables in Perform OA App Using Smart Tables

SAP Fiori smart tables are now used to display component data, PRTs, and data collection for operation activities that have simple work instructions or no work instructions. This modernization provides app extensibility for key users and delivers better look and feel and behavior of the UI.

 

Improved Extensibility in Authoring of Interactive Work Instructions

New Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) have been introduced, which you can use to fill custom fields for components, inspection characteristics, and PRTs that are referenced in both interactive and non-interactive work instructions

 

The custom field values are then displayed in the work instructions in the Perform Operation Activity app.

Want to Find Out More?

You can find more information on all new features provided in SAP S/4HANA Manufacturing for production engineering and operations (PEO) Release 2025 FPS0 here:

  • What's New | SAP Help Portal  – just go to Manufacturing for Production Engineering and Operations
